column2: The whole of the property, consisting of an immense workshop, two pavilions at the bottom of the garden, and the garden itself, had been purchased by Emmanuel, who had seen at a glance that he could make of it a profitable speculation.

column2: My sister is in the garden plucking the dead roses; my brother is reading his two papers, the Presse and the Debats, within six steps of her; for wherever you see Madame Herbault, you have only to look within a circle of four yards and you will find M. Emmanuel, and 'reciprocally,' as they say at the Polytechnic School." At the sound of their steps a young woman of twenty to five and twenty, dressed in a silk morning gown, and busily engaged in plucking the dead leaves off a noisette rose-tree, raised her head. This was Julie, who had become, as the clerk of the house of Thomson & French had predicted, Madame Emmanuel Herbault.

column2: Penelon, replied Julie, "go and inform M. Emmanuel of this gentleman's visit, and Maximilian will conduct him to the salon." column2: He labored and toiled until he had amassed 250,000 francs; six years sufficed to achieve this object.

column2: Oh, I assure you, sir, it was a touching spectacle to see these young creatures, destined by their talents for higher stations, toiling together, and through their unwillingness to change any of the customs of their paternal house, taking six years to accomplish what less scrupulous people would have effected in two or three.

column2: Marseilles resounded with their well-earned praises.

column2: At last, one day, Emmanuel came to his wife, who had just finished making up the accounts.
column3: At last, one day, Emmanuel came to his wife, who had just finished making up the accounts.

column2: 'Julie,' said he to her, 'Cocles has just given me the last rouleau of a hundred francs; that completes the 250,000 francs we had fixed as the limits of our gains. Can you content yourself with the small fortune which we shall possess for the future?
column3: 'Julie,' said he to her, 'Cocles has just given me the last rouleau of a hundred francs; that completes the two hundred fifty thousand francs we had fixed as the limits of our gains. Can you content yourself with the small fortune which we shall possess for the future?

column2: Listen to me.
column3: Listen to me.

column2: Our house transacts business to the amount of a million a year, from which we derive an income of 40,000 francs. We can dispose of the business, if we please, in an hour, for I have received a letter from M. Delaunay, in which he offers to purchase the good-will of the house, to unite with his own, for 300,000 francs. Advise me what I had better do.'--'Emmanuel,' returned my sister, 'the house of Morrel can only be carried on by a Morrel.
column3: Our house transacts business to the amount of a million a year, from which we derive an income of forty thousand francs. We can dispose of the business, if we please, in an hour, for I have received a letter from m Delaunay, in which he offers to purchase the good will of the house, to unite with his own, for three hundred thousand francs. Advise me what I had better do.'--'Emmanuel,' returned my sister, 'the house of Morrel can only be carried on by a Morrel.

column2: Is it not worth 300,000 francs to save our father's name from the chances of evil fortune and failure?'--'I thought so,' replied Emmanuel; 'but I wished to have your advice.'--'This is my counsel:--Our accounts are made up and our bills paid; all we have to do is to stop the issue of any more, and close our office.' This was done instantly.
column3: Is it not worth three hundred thousand francs to save our father's name from the chances of evil fortune and failure?'--'I thought so,' replied Emmanuel; 'but I wished to have your advice.'--'This is my counsel:--Our accounts are made up and our bills paid; all we have to do is to stop the issue of any more, and close our office.' column2: The silence became almost painful when, by a violent effort, tearing himself from his pleasing reverie--"Madame," said he at length, "I pray you to excuse my emotion, which must astonish you who are only accustomed to the happiness I meet here; but contentment is so new a sight to me, that I could never be weary of looking at yourself and your husband."

column2: Monsieur, returned Maximilian, raising the glass cover, and respectfully kissing the silken purse, "this has touched the hand of a man who saved my father from suicide, us from ruin, and our name from shame and disgrace,--a man by whose matchless benevolence we poor children, doomed to want and wretchedness, can at present hear every one envying our happy lot.

column2: Tell me, continued he, "was he not about my height, perhaps a little taller, with his chin imprisoned, as it were, in a high cravat; his coat closely buttoned up, and constantly taking out his pencil?"
column3: Tell me, continued he, "was he not about my height, perhaps a little taller, with his chin imprisoned, as it were, in a high cravat; his coat closely buttoned up, and constantly taking out his pencil?"

column2: Oh, do you then know him? cried Julie, whose eyes sparkled with joy.
column3: Oh, do you then know him? cried Julie, whose eyes sparkled with joy.

column2: No, returned Monte Cristo "I only guessed.
column3: No, returned Monte Cristo "I only guessed.

column2: I knew a Lord Wilmore, who was constantly doing actions of this kind."
column3: I knew a Lord Wilmore, who was constantly doing actions of this kind."

column2: Without revealing himself?
column3: Without revealing himself?

column2: He was an eccentric being, and did not believe in the existence of gratitude.
column3: He was an eccentric being, and did not believe in the existence of gratitude.

column2: Oh, heaven, exclaimed Julie, clasping her hands, "in what did he believe, then?"
column3: Oh, heaven, exclaimed Julie, clasping her hands, "in what did he believe, then?"

column2: He did not credit it at the period which I knew him, said Monte Cristo, touched to the heart by the accents of Julie's voice; "but, perhaps, since then he has had proofs that gratitude does exist."
column3: He did not credit it at the period which I knew him, said Monte Cristo, touched to the heart by the accents of Julie's voice; "but, perhaps, since then he has had proofs that gratitude does exist."

column2: And do you know this gentleman, monsieur? inquired Emmanuel.
column3: And do you know this gentleman, monsieur? inquired Emmanuel.

column2: Oh, if you do know him, cried Julie, "can you tell us where he is--where we can find him?
column3: Oh, if you do know him, cried Julie, "can you tell us where he is-where we can find him?

column2: Maximilian--Emmanuel--if we do but discover him, he must believe in the gratitude of the heart!" Monte Cristo felt tears start into his eyes, and he again walked hastily up and down the room.
column3: Maximilian-Emmanuel-if we do but discover him, he must believe in the gratitude of the heart!" Monte Cristo felt tears start into his eyes, and he again walked hastily up and down the room.

column2: In the name of heaven, said Maximilian, "if you know anything of him, tell us what it is."
column3: In the name of heaven, said Maximilian, "if you know anything of him, tell us what it is."

column2: Alas, cried Monte Cristo, striving to repress his emotion, "if Lord Wilmore was your unknown benefactor, I fear you will never see him again.
column3: Alas, cried Monte Cristo, striving to repress his emotion, "if Lord Wilmore was your unknown benefactor, I fear you will never see him again.

column2: I parted from him two years ago at Palermo, and he was then on the point of setting out for the most remote regions; so that I fear he will never return."
column3: I parted from him two years ago at Palermo, and he was then on the point of setting out for the most remote regions; so that I fear he will never return."

column2: Oh, monsieur, this is cruel of you, said Julie, much affected; and the young lady's eyes swam with tears.
column3: Oh, monsieur, this is cruel of you, said Julie, much affected; and the young lady's eyes swam with tears.

column2: Madame, replied Monte Cristo gravely, and gazing earnestly on the two liquid pearls that trickled down Julie's cheeks, "had Lord Wilmore seen what I now see, he would become attached to life, for the tears you shed would reconcile him to mankind;" and he held out his hand to Julie, who gave him hers, carried away by the look and accent of the count.
column3: Madame, replied Monte Cristo gravely, and gazing earnestly on the two liquid pearls that trickled down Julie's cheeks, "had Lord Wilmore seen what I now see, he would become attached to life, for the tears you shed would reconcile him to mankind;" and he held out his hand to Julie, who gave him hers, carried away by the look and accent of the count.

column2: But, continued she, "Lord Wilmore had a family or friends, he must have known some one, can we not--"
column3: But, continued she, "Lord Wilmore had a family or friends, he must have known some one, can we not-"

column2: Oh, it is useless to inquire, returned the count; "perhaps, after all, he was not the man you seek for.
column3: Oh, it is useless to inquire, returned the count; "perhaps, after all, he was not the man you seek for.

column2: He was my friend: he had no secrets from me, and if this had been so he would have confided in me."
column3: He was my friend: he had no secrets from me, and if this had been so he would have confided in me."

column2: And he told you nothing?
column3: And he told you nothing?

column2: Not a word.
column3: Not a word.

column2: Nothing that would lead you to suppose?
column3: Nothing that would lead you to suppose?

column2: Nothing.
column3: Nothing.

column2: And yet you spoke of him at once.
column3: And yet you spoke of him at once.

column2: Ah, in such a case one supposes--
column3: Ah, in such a case one supposes--

column2: Sister, sister, said Maximilian, coming to the count's aid, "monsieur is quite right.
column3: Sister, sister, said Maximilian, coming to the count's aid, "monsieur is quite right.

column2: Recollect what our excellent father so often told us, 'It was no Englishman that thus saved us.'" Monte Cristo started.
column3: Recollect what our excellent father so often told us, 'It was no Englishman that thus saved us.'" Monte Cristo started.

column2: What did your father tell you, M. Morrel? said he eagerly.
column3: What did your father tell you, m Morrel? said he eagerly.

column2: My father thought that this action had been miraculously performed--he believed that a benefactor had arisen from the grave to save us.	My father thought that this action had been miraculously performed-he believed that a benefactor had arisen from the grave to save us.
column3: true

column2: Oh, it was a touching superstition, monsieur, and although I did not myself believe it, I would not for the world have destroyed my father's faith. How often did he muse over it and pronounce the name of a dear friend--a friend lost to him forever; and on his death-bed, when the near approach of eternity seemed to have illumined his mind with supernatural light, this thought, which had until then been but a doubt, became a conviction, and his last words were, 'Maximilian, it was Edmond Dantes!'" At these words the count's paleness, which had for some time been increasing, became alarming; he could not speak; he looked at his watch like a man who has forgotten the hour, said a few hurried words to Madame Herbault, and pressing the hands of Emmanuel and Maximilian,--"Madame," said he, "I trust you will allow me to visit you occasionally; I value your friendship, and feel grateful to you for your welcome, for this is the first time for many years that I have thus yielded to my feelings;" and he hastily quitted the apartment.
column3: Oh, it was a touching superstition, monsieur, and although I did not myself believe it, I would not for the world have destroyed my father's faith. How often did he muse over it and pronounce the name of a dear friend-a friend lost to him forever; and on his death bed, when the near approach of eternity seemed to have illumined his mind with supernatural light, this thought, which had until then been but a doubt, became a conviction, and his last words were, 'Maximilian, it was Edmond Dantes!'" At these words the count's paleness, which had for some time been increasing, became alarming; he could not speak; he looked at his watch like a man who has forgotten the hour, said a few hurried words to Madame Herbault, and pressing the hands of Emmanuel and Maximilian,--"Madame," said he, "I trust you will allow me to visit you occasionally; I value your friendship, and feel grateful to you for your welcome, for this is the first time for many years that I have thus yielded to my feelings;" and he hastily quitted the apartment.

column2: This Count of Monte Cristo is a strange man, said Emmanuel.
column3: This Count of Monte Cristo is a strange man, said Emmanuel.

column2: Yes, answered Maximilian, "but I feel sure he has an excellent heart, and that he likes us."
column3: Yes, answered Maximilian, "but I feel sure he has an excellent heart, and that he likes us."

column2: His voice went to my heart, observed Julie; "and two or three times I fancied that I had heard it before."
column3: His voice went to my heart, observed Julie; "and two or three times I fancied that I had heard it before."
